intro: Phagnalon calycinum subsp. ballsianum, commonly known as the Ball's mountain phagnalon, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to high-altitude regions of South America. It belongs to the family Asteraceae, characterized by its composite flower heads and robust stem structure. The plant typically grows in rocky or alpine environments, demonstrating adaptability to harsh climatic conditions. Its leaves are generally lanceolate and covered with fine hairs, while its flowers are small and clustered in composite heads. This subspecies is of interest in botanical studies due to its unique ecological adaptations and potential medicinal properties.
